conclusion: To determine heat absorption vs. release, analyze processes in the p-V diagram.
Cycle consists of two adiabatic and two isochoric processes.
Adiabatic processes: no heat exchange, work due to internal energy change.
Isochoric processes: volume constant, work is zero, heat changes internal energy.
Process c to b: Adiabatic compression (volume decreases, pressure increases).
Process b to a: Isochoric cooling (volume constant, pressure decreases).
Process a to d: Adiabatic expansion (volume increases, pressure decreases).
Process d to c: Isochoric heating (volume constant, pressure increases).
Adiabatic processes (c to b and a to d) have no heat exchange.
Isochoric b to a: heat released; Isochoric d to c: heat absorbed.
Net heat exchange depends on magnitudes of heat absorbed and released.
Net work done by gas is positive as cycle is clockwise.
First law of thermodynamics: net heat added equals net work done plus change in internal energy.
For complete cycle, change in internal energy is zero.
Net heat added equals net work done.
Since net work done is positive, net heat added is positive.
Heat absorbed during d to c is greater than heat released during b to a.
Final answer: Heat absorbed is greater than heat released during complete cycle.
